mainClaim: Cultivated meat could dramatically reduce environmental impact of food production while meeting protein demands
evidence: Oxford lifecycle analysis shows cultivated meat uses 95% less land, 78% less water, and produces 96% fewer greenhouse gas emissions than conventional beef. Current global livestock system uses 77% of agricultural land but provides only 18% of calories. Scaling cultivated meat could free 3 billion hectares for rewilding/carbon sequestration. Good Food Institute projects price parity with conventional meat by 2030 as production scales.
supportingPoints: Eliminates animal welfare concerns and zoonotic disease risks
Precision nutrition - can optimize fatty acid profiles and reduce harmful compounds
Reduces antibiotic use - livestock consume 70% of world's antibiotics
Food security - decouples protein production from land/water availability
limitations: Current production energy-intensive and expensive. Consumer acceptance uncertain. Disruption to livestock farmers and rural economies. Nutritional profile and long-term health effects need more study. Scale-up challenges remain.
